resources.string: Open debug menu
Back
Coming soon…
No application can handle this link
Setup
Welcome!\n\nBeagle is a free and open-source library that adds a smart and easily customizable debug menu to the internal builds of your Android apps.
Check it out on GitHub

In this demo application you can trigger the debug menu at any time by shaking the device (one decided shake is enough, think of your phone as a judge's gavel), or by tapping on the Beagle logo in the bottom-right corner.

The following sections provide some guidance with setting up the library while the rest of the app serves as a demo / showcase for the built-in feature set.
Initialization
The first step towards having Beagle in your project is making sure that the JitPack Maven repository is added to the allprojects block of your project-level build.gradle file.
The library offers five variants that display the debug menu in different ways. The next step is selecting the one that fits your application\'s needs the most…
Activity
Bottom sheet
Dialog
Drawer
View
…and adding the following dependencies to the module-level build.gradle file:

Specifying the noop variant for release builds ensures that none of Beagle\'s functionality makes its way to production, but you can still use the same public API without getting compilation errors.\n\nAfter adding the dependencies, the library can be initialized with a single line of code in the onCreate() method of your custom Application class:
Module configuration
At this point, if you run your app, you should be able to trigger an empty debug menu. To make it more useful, we should configure a list of modules.
Beagle provides multiple ways to set or change the list of modules, the simplest of which is calling:

This function can be called at any time, from any thread, to replace the current configuration with a new list of modules (provided as varargs).

In case you only want to change some parts of the debug menu without affecting the others, there are functions that give you more granular control over the modules.

For adding one or more modules you can use this:

In this function, the optional placement parameter can be used to specify the position of the new modules (first, last, or above / below a module that\'s already part of the menu). Specifying the optional lifecycleOwner will automatically remove the modules when that lifecycle is over, which is ideal for elements that are specific to a single screen.\n\nThe following function exists for manually removing one or more modules from the debug menu, using their ID-s:

As you can see, ID-s must be unique for modules: if two instances are added with the same ID, only one will be handled. Most modules automatically generate a unique ID for themselves that you only need to override in special cases, but some of them don\'t support this option as they were designed to be added only once. The ID-s for these types of modules are public constants in the module class: ModuleName.ID.\n\nLast but not least, the following function is exposed to get you the reference for an already added module instance:

Check out the rest of this demo to see what you can achieve with the built-in modules. The Examples page contains a list of case studies showcasing various situations where Beagle can be useful (with code snippets to show how each specific debug menu is created), while the Playground page provides an interactive tool for previewing any possible combination of modules.
Troubleshooting

In case of the Drawer UI, if you have overwritten the Activity\'s onBackPressed() method, you might notice that the default back navigation handling does not always work as expected. To fix this, in every Activity\'s onBackPressed() you should check that Beagle.hide() returns false before doing any other checks or calling the super implementation:

If you can\'t seem to trigger Beagle in your app, make sure you\'re not adding any Fragments to the container with the ID android.R.id.content (if that\'s the case, introducing another FrameLayout into the View hierarchy for debug builds is a simple fix to the problem).\n\nIf you find any undocumented problems, feel free to reach out and open an issue on GitHub - I\'ll be quick to respond.

This is the debug menu configured by you

It should contain useful information, like the version number of your app, the build date, or information on the device it's running on.

You can use it to track network requests, show analytics events, display custom logs, session-related data, or anything that you consider useful for debugging potential issues or simplifying the testing process.

It can also contain various interactive features, such as switches, radio groups, buttons, sliders, etc. that you can use to set up a "God mode" during development.
Show app info
Take a screenshot
Development
Staging
Production
The contents of the debug menu can be changed at any time. For example, in this app you will see very different Beagle setups as you explore the different screens.
Examples

The module configuration very much depends on your application\'s specific needs, so there is no single setup that will be ideal for every situation.\n\nThe following examples demonstrate some of the library\'s features while also describing how they are implemented. Use them as inspiration for coming up with your own debug menu!
Select one of the case studies to see the specialized version of the debug menu for the situation.
You can also navigate from here, why not?
Simple setup
Built-in modules that can be added with no configuration whatsoever and are useful for most projects.
Open the debug menu to check out its features. The current module configuration is initialized using the following code snippet:
All of these modules can be customized by specifying some optional parameters, but for this example the default values are used. Let\'s see what each individual module does:\n

A shortcut to the system settings page of your app. Can be useful if you need quick access to clearing the storage, for example.\n\nThe optional shouldOpenInNewTask parameter can be used to specify the FLAG_ACTIVITY_NEW_TASK Intent flag for the new Activity.
A shortcut to the system\'s Developer Options page.\n\nThe optional shouldOpenInNewTask parameter can be used to specify the FLAG_ACTIVITY_NEW_TASK Intent flag for the new Activity.
This module can be used to easily test the application\'s crash reporting capabilities.

Create a screenshot image of the current screen and bring up the system's Share bottom sheet, when done.

The image will be saved in the app's private cache folder and exposed using a FileProvider to avoid asking for storage permission.

Below Android 5.0 the drawing cache of the root view will be used which is not ideal: system decorations or dialogs might not be visible. On Android 5.0 and above the MediaProjectionManager API is used which creates a proper screenshot, but requires the user to give their permission every time (due to privacy concerns).

Some aspects of the screenshot flow can be customized using the Appearance and Behavior objects that were provided when initializing Beagle.

Create a video recording of the current screen and bring up the system's Share bottom sheet, when done.

The recording is handled by a foreground service and a system notification will be present for the entire duration of the recording. The capture can be stopped by tapping on that notification.

The video will be saved in the app's private cache folder and exposed using a FileProvider to avoid asking for storage permission.

The implementation relies on the MediaProjectionManager API which is only available on Android 5.0 and above, and requires the user to give their permission every time (due to privacy concerns).

Some aspects of the screen recording flow can be customized using the Appearance and Behavior objects that were provided when initializing Beagle.

This switch can be very useful when trying to create pixel-perfect layouts. The color and dimensions of the overlay grid are configurable, but the default values follow the Material Design specifications for mobile and tablet.
A frequent use case for this toggle is debugging animation or transition glitches. Check out how it affects this loading indicator:
Displays important information about the device such as the Android SDK version or the screen resolution that can be helpful in identifying device-specific issues.
Static data
Ways to display potentially useful information about the build, the environment or the session.
Here are all the modules used in this example:
Again, let\'s discuss them individually, in detail.\n
This module applies a specific formatting to three (optional) pieces of text. The variables for the current configuration are defined the following way:
The last line uses a custom build config field:
A setup like this is usually a good candidate for the first item of the debug menu as it displays all the important metadata about the build at a glance.

One of the simplest modules, displaying just a piece of text. Please note that all modules that deal with text drawn on the UI expect CharSequence instead of String. As a result, while Strings are perfectly fine, spannables can also be used to spice things up with special formatting.

Similar to TextModule, but the main content (text parameter) can be collapsed into a header (title parameter). The isExpandedInitially parameter can be used to specify whether or not the content should be expanded the first time the user opens the debug menu.
Basically a TextModule with bold formatting, where the text parameter has been renamed to title. Ideal for short section headers.
Adds 8dp of empty space to the debug menu. Feel free to add more than one instances if more space is needed.
A 1dp tall, horizontal line that uses the default text color of the theme.

Similar to LongTextModule in its expand-collapse behavior, but instead of a single text parameter for its main content, this module expects a list of CharSequence Pairs. The keys for each entry will automatically become bold.
This piece of text contains parts with special formatting.
Labels can be used to separate content, but adding spaces…
…or dividers…
…can also be useful.
Longer pieces of content can be made expandable.
This helps reduce visual clutter and also acts as a way to organize the debug menu.
Another way to display information is to group it into key-value pairs.
Key 1
Value 1
Key 2
Value 2
Key 3
Value 3
Feature flags
Test different implementations without creating new builds, and persist these settings across app launches with a single extra line of code.

Enabling / disabling some toggles or changing some specific part of the configuration at runtime is one of the most important use cases for a debug menu. This example showcases all the ways Beagle can help you achieve this.\n\nObserve how the values in the card below are updated in real-time as you modify the flags in the debug menu:
ON
OFF
"• Toggle 1: "
"\n• Toggle 2: "
"\n• Toggle 3: "
"\n• Toggle 4: "
"\n• Check box group: "
"\n• Radio button group: "
"\n• Slider: "
"\n• Text input: "

The simplest way to initialize a Switch module is providing a text parameter together with a callback lambda, which will be invoked with the Boolean argument of the new state every time the user toggles the switch:
Initially the switch will be off, but this can be changed by overriding the default value of the initialValue parameter.
Check boxes can be initialized in a very similar way to switches and they support the same functionality. The only difference is the name of the module:
For items that are grouped together into a list we should create a model class representation for list items that implements the BeagleListItemContract interface:

After this we can define the module by specifying a list of items as well as a title for the list, the set of the initial selection ID-s and the callback (which will be invoked with the set of currently selected items as its argument).

In case of radio buttons, the important difference compared to the previous example is that at most a single item can be selected at any given time. As a result, there is no need to deal with sets any more:
The module supports not having an initial selection, so both the initiallySelectedItemId parameter and the argument of the onSelectionChanged lambda are nullable.
Adjusting the value of an integer within a specified range can be done using the SliderModule:

One interesting aspect to note here is that the text displayed on top of the seek bar is defined as a lambda that receives the current value (after every change event) and returns a CharSequence.\n\nThe optional parameters to configure the behavior of the slider are minimumValue, maximumValue and initialValue (the latter defaults to minimumValue, if not specified).
Somewhat similar in API to Slider but this module deals with a String value instead of an Int.

The item itself is just a clickable text, that brings up a dialog which contains the actual text input. The areRealTimeUpdatesEnabled parameter controls whether or not the value should be updated after every keystroke (and as a result, the callback will be invoked on every change event), or only after the user presses the Done button. The validator lambda exposes the option to reject certain values, while doneText and cancelText can be used to customize the appearance of the dialog.

string.name: case_study_feature_flags_querying_and_changing_the_current_value
string.b: Querying and changing the current value

resources.string: In case using the callbacks for the modules above is not enough, the current state can be queried at any time using this (somewhat cumbersome) function:
A similar setter also exists to modify the state programatically.
Any changes made this way will also update the UI. Give it a try with this button:

To use any of these methods, a reference to the module is needed. The simplest way to get that is saving it at the moment of instantiation, but if that is not convenient for some reason, the library\'s find() function can also be used.
Please note that this will return null if the module is not currently added to the debug menu, but it will throw a ClassCastException if the module was found with a different type, than expected.
Reset all
All values were reset

All of the modules discussed in this example have the optional isValuePersisted constructor parameter, which is set to false by default. Setting it to true AND providing a unique module ID (the auto-generated random value is inconsistent between app launches) will automatically save and restore the state of the module to / from SharedPreferences.

If the value is persisted, the initialValue / initiallySelectedItemIds / initiallySelectedItemId parameters are only taken into consideration when there is no data saved on the local storage.

Lastly, the callbacks of persisted modules are invoked when the module is added to the debug menu so that any custom logic that happens on manual selection could also be executed when the state is restored.

The current demo configuration saves and restores all the modules on this screen.
Right now all manual changes made to the modules are applied instantaneously. You can change that:
Right now all manual changes made to the modules are only applied after a confirmation. You can change that:

By setting the shouldRequireConfirmation parameter to true for any of the modules presented in this example, users will be given the option to Apply or Reset the changes they made. This means that the library will accumulate pending change events and invoke the necessary callbacks in bulk when the user presses the Apply button.\n\nModifying the values from code will still have instantaneous effect. The texts that appear on the Apply and Reset buttons can be changed in the optional Appearance object provided while initializing Beagle.

resources.string: Text input
Current value: %s (tap on this item to change it)
Intercepting network requests
See the incoming and outgoing REST API calls and their formatted JSON payload to quickly debug potential issues.

The lyrics for these songs are downloaded from the internet every time you change the selection.

Observe how the debug menu tracks every outgoing and incoming network request. You can also tap on the individual entries to see the formatted JSON payload.
Loading…
Something went wrong.
Try again
Eagles - Hotel California
The Rembrandts - I\'ll Be There for You
The Proclaimers - I\'m Gonna Be (500 Miles)
\nThe module itself can be instantiated using a single line of code:
However, it will only start working if a special interceptor is registered on the OkHttpClient used by the requests.

The cumbersome casting was the only way to avoid the noop variant depending on OkHttp, sorry about that.\n\nIf, for some reason, you cannot use this interceptor (for example in case of socket-based API-s), the library exposes the Beagle.logNetworkEvent(…) function which populates the same module. Furthermore, you can use Beagle.clearNetworkLogs() to reset the list at any time.
Clear logs
Logs cleared

As usual, the optional arguments of the module constructor can be used to fine-tune its behavior:
 • Specifying a baseUrl is a good idea in most cases to avoid having the same URL prefix for every single entry.
 • maxItemCount limits the total number of entries displayed in the list (and defaults to 10, when not specified).
 • The timestampFormatter lambda can be used to override the way the timestamps of the events are displayed (or set to null to remove displaying timestamps altogether).

The library also provides a way to listen to any updates made to the list of network log events through the NetworkLogListener interface which can be used with the Beagle.addNetworkLogListener(), Beagle.removeNetworkLogListener(), and Beagle.clearNetworkLogListeners() functions.
Logging analytics events
Making sure that every required event is tracked from an admin panel can be cumbersome. Why not display the events right in the app, in real time?
Analytics events
Check out how any state change made to the following four check boxes is tracked by the debug menu:\n
Toggle 1
Toggle 2
Toggle 3
Toggle 4

This was achieved using Beagle\'s logging capabilities (and logging analytics events is of course just a small subset of the potential use cases for the feature). A single log() function is invoked every time a change is made:

The tag parameter is optional, and is there to help with filtering, as multiple instances of LogListModule can be present at any time in the menu, each distinguished by the tag they are set up to track. If no tag is provided for the module, it will display all log messages.
All of the parameters from the constructor above are optional and have reasonable default values.\n\nThe list of log entries can be cleared any time using:
Again, not providing a tag would signal the intention of clearing all messages, regardless of tag. See it in action:

\nLast bug not least, it is worth pointing out that, similarly to the NetworkLogListModule, we have the option to override the default timestmap formatting using the timestampFormatter parameter, and listen to changes with the LogListener interface (used with the Beagle.addLogListener(), Beagle.removeLogListener(), and Beagle.clearLogListeners() functions).
Clear logs
Logs cleared
Authentication
Simplify the QA process by presenting a list of test accounts and automatically filling in the necessary login information.
Manually typing in the same credentials multiple times a day can be a huge waste of time.
Email address
Password
Sign in
Signing in!
To define a module that helps in this situation, first we need to create a representation of a test account:

Extending BeagleListItemContract is a must as it provides information to the library about a unique identifier for the model (in this case the email address is good enough), and the actual text that is displayed on the UI.\n\nThe next step is creating the module:

To simplify the flow further, in the callback lambda we\'re hiding the debug menu and simulating the button press to proceed with the sign in flow.\n\nAnother idea to save time is to automatically display the debug menu when the screen is opened, simply by calling:
You can test this implementation by toggling the \"Show automatically\" switch and re-opening this screen.
Environment switcher
Change the application\'s base URL at runtime.
Mock data generator
Filling your development database with random content like \"d23fMIMnow81\" makes your app look bad. Why not add a simple Lorem Ipsum generator instead?
Bug reporting tool
Fetch Beagle, take a screenshot, draw on it, provide additional details, add configurable build and device information and send them to an email address, or create a Jira ticket directly.
Playground

Use this interactive tool to quickly preview any module configuration and generate the code that can be used to create it. The debug menu will be updated automatically, in real time.

• Drag the items vertically to rearrange them
• Swipe the items horizontally to remove them
• Press the last button to add new items
Add a new module
The current configuration could be created with something like this:
Add new module
Generic modules\nAny number of instances can be added
Button
Displays a simple button.
CheckBox
Displays a simple check box.
Divider
Displays a simple horizontal line.
ItemList
Displays a list of simple items represented by [BeagleListItemContract].
KeyValueList
Displays a list of key-value pairs that can be collapsed into a header.
Label
Displays a section header label.
LogList
Displays an expandable list of log messages. An example use case could be logging analytics events
LongText
Displays a longer piece of text that can be collapsed into a title.
MultipleSelectionList
Displays a list of check boxes represented by [BeagleListItemContract] instances. Any number of items can be selected at any given time.
Padding
Adds empty space between two other modules
SingleSelectionList
Displays a list of radio buttons represented by [BeagleListItemContract] instances. Only one item is selected at any given time.
Slider
Allows the user to adjust a numeric value.
Switch
Displays a simple switch.
Text
Displays a piece of text. Can be used for click handling as well.
TextInput
Allows the user to enter a text value.
Unique modules\nOnly a single instance can be added
AnimationDurationSwitch
Displays a switch that, when enabled, increases the duration of animations.
AppInfoButton
Displays a button that links to the system settings\' Developer Options page.
DeveloperOptionsButton
Displays a button that links to the Android App Info page for your app.
DeviceInfo
Displays information about the current device and the OS.
ForceCrashButton
Displays a button that throws an exception when pressed - useful for testing crash reporting.
Header
Displays a configurable title, subtitle and text.
KeylineOverlaySwitch
Displays a switch that, when enabled, draws a grid over your app with configurable dimensions that you can use to check the alignments of your Views.
NetworkLogList
Displays an expandable list of historical network activity. The entries are clickable to inspect their JSON payloads.
ScreenRecordingButton
Displays a button that takes a screen recording video of the current layout and allows the user to share it (only available on Android 5.0 Lollipop and above).
ScreenshotButton
Displays a button that takes a screenshot image of the current layout and allows the user to share it.
About

Beagle is developed by me, Pandula Péter. Thanks for taking the time to check it out - I hope you\'ll find it useful in your projects. If you have any issues, questions or ideas, don\'t hesitate to contact me!\n
This build depends on version %s of the Beagle library.
GitHub repository\nCheck out the source code
Play Store listing\nRate the app on Google Play
Share\nSpread the word about Beagle
Check out Beagle, a free and open-source Android library that adds a highly customizable debug menu to the internal builds of your apps: %s
